body: @spmallette thanks

I think this was meant to be `createClassic()` - note the use of float values for the "weight" property.  

@okram any recollection on why we used classic here at all?  would it be better to demonstrate graph structure with modern since it includes vertex labels?
Ah, good point. So it's not quite equivalent to either classic or modern.
@velo do you have thoughts on how to proceed with windows CI now that we know apache infra doesn't currently support that?

Glad you figured out how to get that pull request done - cool! A few things:
1. Travis is failing, but i dont think that's your fault - from the looks of the output it seems that Travis just died mid build somehow. I can test the build of your PR manually when the time comes.
2. could you quickly edit the name of your PR to be prefixed with the JIRA issue? That will allow our comments to hook into JIRA nicely for all comments on this ticket. In other words, just change the title to "TINKERPOP-1125 Use the existing Host iterator"
3. Did you run the Gremlin Server integration tests?  Basically, after `mvn clean install` you can just do: `mvn verify -DskipIntegrationTests=false -pl gremlin-server`. Those don't get executed by Travis. 

Sorry for the extra "administrative" work and I can't imagine you've broken anything with this change, but I just would like you to know what our pull request procedure looks like.  You can read more about such things here in the contributor docs:

http://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/3.1.0-incubating/developer.html#_pull_request_format

Last but not least, the tp31 branch is currently frozen for release of 3.1.1-incubating which will go up for vote on Monday, so we probably won't look to merge this in until that is all settled.  Thanks again - please keep the PRs coming. :smile:

1) I hope not!
2) Done.
3) No I didn't run these.  I'll do this shortly and update here.

Ran the integration tests, no errors, though lots of stack traces.

thanks - travis is still failing strangely - same error.  not sure what's wrong there, but i still don't think it has anything to do with your PR.
Hmm, I added a commit for TINKERPOP-1127 to my branch.  I guess it gets included in this PR, hope this is ok.

Not a big deal if you find it necessary to combine the work, but better to create a new branch for each JIRA issue when possible. I notice that you are submitting your PR from your the `tp31` branch of your fork.  In the future you might prefer to create a branch from `tp31` called `TINKERPOP-1127` then submit your PR from that to our `tp31`.  In that way your work gets isolated a little better and you can pull in the latest from our `tp31` without conflict if you need to.  Just provides a bit more flexibility.

VOTE: +1

Reevaluated my previous tests.

Still: +1
Short of there being some consensus to convert "classic" to "modern" in the docs, I don't think there's anything to change here.  Going to close this.
+1 - did `mvn clean install` and some basic review of the code itself.

VOTE +1. `mvn clean install`, integration tested, and built/published docs.

You can review the docs here: http://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/3.2.0-SNAPSHOT/reference/

I guess you should update the PR to remove the appveyor stuff then.  

@pluradj have you had a look at this PR yet?  would be nice to get your review/vote as you have a windows environment that you could test it out on...

Why do you use a different order to your methods? Why not copy the parameterization from `Vertex`?

```
id, ?vertex?, label, vertex, properties...
```
I don't even know why you have `ScriptElementFactory` now. Why not just make available a static `getOrCreate()` and get rid of `ScriptElementFactory` ?

I can think about another API for TP 3.2, but this PR is for TP 3.1.2.

EDIT: I just realized that the PR was created for a merge into `master/`. Going to fix that.

I was looking more into this. I think we should `Deprecate` ScriptElementFactory. Why not just use `StarGraph` directly? Your `vertex()`-logic is identical to `StarGraph.addVertex()`. Note that if its the `StarVertex`, it comes right back. If its not a new `StarAdjacentVertex` is created and returned.

I would recommend.
1. Do not add more methods to `ScriptElementFactory`.
2. Deprecate `ScriptElementFactory` in TP 3.2.0.
3. Update to use `StarGraph` directly, but if the user's script has a method for `ScriptElementFactory`, then use that method.
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-1144
What's the remaining lifetime of something that is marked as deprecated? Can we deprecate ScriptElementFactory for 3.1.2 and remove it in 3.2.0?
No. We leave it around indefinitely. We may do a "big purge" at 3.5.0.
I've found no way to inject the `graph` as a global variable. I can either add another `parse` method parameter, which would break existing code, or I can add `ScriptElementFactory::getGraph()`.
I ran `mvn clean install`. All good. VOTE +1.

I've merged this PR to a TinkerPop branch called `TINKERPOP-1125-to-1127` for internal code review.   it covers this PR and #213  

That branch looks all good with:

``` text
mvn clean install && mvn verify -pl gremlin-server -DskipIntegrationTests=false
```

I will update CHANGELOG after merge.  

VOTE +1
I've merged this PR to a TinkerPop branch called `TINKERPOP-1125-to-1127` for internal code review.   it covers this PR and #211 - please see the VOTE there.

This is looking much better. Given that this is backwards compatible (nice Exception catching trick BTW), can you make at least one of the script.groovy in the old model so we know that backwards compatibility with Deprecated ScriptElementFactory is preserved. When we ultimately drop ScriptElementFactory, we then fix up the old script.groovy.
Reverted the changes in `grateful-dead-script-input.groovy`, so it's using the old model. `script-input.groovy` uses the new model.  Both scripts are used in unit tests, thus each case is covered.
VOTE +1.

Note that when TINKERPOP-1140 is completed, `traversal.getStrategies().onGraphComputer()` will be replaced by `TraversalHelper.onGraphComputer(traversal)`. Minor note as this is one of the breaking changes for providers.
BTW, @pluradj  any idea on what to do on the broken tests?

- `mvn clean install`: passed
- integration tests (incl. Neo4j): passed

VOTE: +1

One negative note though: Strategies are mainly responsible for a significant performance gap between graph methods and their respective traversal methods. As we've seen in the past, `.stream()...` performs terrible compared to an old school `for` loop, hence I don't think we should use `.stream()` so frequently in new code. Better we get rid of `.stream()` altogether.

Looks good

@dkuppitz -- where in particular are you seeing the use of `stream()`?
VOTE +1. I will be so happy to see the "randomness" removed from our integration testing. Thanks @spmallette.

At least some of these code lines were probably copied from somewhere else as part of the refactoring process. However, as said before, it would probably be better to get rid of `stream()` once we stumble across it in the code we're working on.

Code looks good, `mvn clean install` passed...

VOTE: +1

A response to each item in your list.
- This will go away when TINKERPOP-1140 is complete. This is a "staging method" for now.
- This is not a critical performance line of code. This is during `TraversalSource` construction which is like saying "a database connection creation method uses stream."
- Same as previous.
- Same as previous -- submitting a `GraphComputer` job is crazy costly relative to this simple `stream()`.
- This will go away when TINKERPOP-1140 is complete. This is a "staging method" for now.
- This is test suite setup code. Performance doesn't matter.
- Same as previous.

To your "old code" reference:
- Yes, we should not use `stream()` here. This class needs to be blazing fast. I believe you and I are the author of this class and we should fix it. That is for another ticket.

NOTE: We should also remove all the `stream()` work in `StarGraph` (there is a butt load).

Code looks good, `mvn clean install` passed...

VOTE: +1
VOTE +1
@velo I've been digging around on it. Haven't figured anything out yet.
+1 on appveyor enablement

Did a basic build with `mvn clean install` and reviewed docs - looks good:

VOTE +1

Perhaps we should re-calibrate a bit here. The original ticket was about getting the `StructureStandardTestSuite` working on windows (which can be a blocker for graph providers doing dev on windows).  As far as i can gather, that much is fixed.  As a bonus, @velo got us a build on windows through appveyor and even got apache infra to enable it for us.

There are some good fixes in this PR as-is and it would be nice to see appveyors yaml in the main dev branches.  Since the original issue is resolved, let's get this PR up for VOTE.  To do that, we need appveyor yaml to change slightly so that it doesn't fail the build.  Since the tests don't all pass, @velo can you please change the build to `-Dspark-gremlin.skip.tests=true` or maybe even skip just the failing tests `-Dspark-gremlin.test.excludes="**/*ExcludeTest.java` - we do that temporarily until a separate pull request can address those failures (we'll need a new ticket obviously).

Does that sound reasonable?
Reviewed code. VOTE +1.

- `mvn clean install`: passed
- integration tests: passed

Wonderful addition.

VOTE: +1

I decided to write the docs. Docs written. Note that they don't build. This has nothing to do with this PR. It has to do with the recent fix to the `manifest` for Neo4j plugin. Neo4j pulls in Scala 2.11.x while Spark uses 2.10.x. The doc builder (having all plugins installed at once) makes it so Spark uses Scala 2.11.x and there are "NoMethodDefinedExceptions." This effects `tp31` branch, but not `master/` as master will (in a later ticket) bump to Spark 1.6.0 which uses Scala 2.11.x.

I'm going to run the full integration tests on ubuntu just to be sure nothing is busted there. @spmallette Off the top of my head:
1.  Maybe security through obfuscation?  But this is a open source library and one can easily know which method does what based on matching the version of the library with the type signatures
2.  This will make class files a little larger since before Java8 only the method signature was stored.  Also this does appear to only be supported by Java8, which is fine since Tinkerpop requires it:  https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/tools/windows/javac.html.  Note, not there for Java7.

I do see some mention of the larger memory footprint issue here:  http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/reflect/member/methodparameterreflection.html.  So that is a consideration.  In this case, with gremlin-core the difference seems to be about 100K when looking at the uncompressed class file size difference.
